div.head: Concerning the text
div.p:
Praeterea considerandum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 28, xxx
. This is distinction 28 in which, after the Master treated about proper properties, now he intends to speak about some other things. And it is divided into two parts according to the two properties that he posits, therefore in the first place he treats the first, and in the second place about the second at the beginning of distinction 29,
praeterea aliud nomen
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 29
. The first part is divided into three because in the first place he treats about the property of being unbegotten, in the second place about the condition of being begotten, and in the third place .... The second begins at
illud etiam taceri non oportet
Lombardus, Sent. XXX . The third begins at
sciendum quoque
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
.

The second principal part, in which the Master treats about the second property or notion which is active spirtation, is divided into three because in the first place he shows multiple meanings of principle, in the second place he offers regarding this one question or his intention, and in the third place the declaration of this. The second begins at
Omnium ergo, quae naturaliter sunt
Lombardus, Sent. I, Distinctio 29, c. 2
The third at ....

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether the Father speaking his eternal Word is able to be called the internal principle of the Word; whether the supposite speaking the eternal Word is able to be called non-impedible internal principle of the word

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p:
That not because, if there were some word in the divine, then that would either be said essentially or relatively. Not relatively because a word is an act of the intellect according to its own manifestation which is not said relatively. Again in the second place because according to
Augustine, book XV De Trinitate, in chapter 19
verbum est cum amore notitia
Augustinus, De Trinitate IX,
. But knowledge is not said relatively, but essentially about any person, therefore. Nor should it be said that the word is said essentially because according to
Augustine, in the aforesaid book, chapter 17
in this Trinity word is only said of the son
Augustinus, XV De Trinitate c. 29

In the second place principally thus, there are several understandings or utterances in the divine, therefore there are many words there or nothing should be put there. The consequent is false. And the consequence is clear because with respect to any utterance there is a giving of a word. The antecedent is clear through
Anselm, Monologion, chapter 62 , where he says that
every person speaks itself
Anselmus, Monologion c. 62, xxx
.

In the third place, in the divine there is no beginning. Proof, because this would either through an internal or external relation. Not the first because the beginning and the cause are the same, as is held in
IV and V Metaphysics
Aristoteles, Metaphysicae XXX
, but no cause should be posited in the divine through an internal relation, therefore. Nor the second because it is produced internally equally, perfectly or even more perfectly, than it is produced externally. And in the second place because then, just as three supposites produce three created things, so three principles begin three begun things, which is false. And the consequence is clear
since any of these supposites is the principle with respect to what is creatable.

On the contrary is the
Master in these distinctions
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. XXX, c. xxx
, where puts forward Augustine for his position.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
First conclusion: just as the Word or Son is the operative art of omnipotence, so it is the infallible declarative knowledge of every true thing. The first part is from
Augustine, VI De Trinitate, in the last chapter , who says, the divine Word or Son of God is the art
is the art of omnipotence full of every living reason
Augustinus, De Trinitate VI, 10, 11
. The second part is clear through
the same author in 83 questions, question 63
et
On John
in the beginning was the word Ioannes 1:1
saying
in this place the Word would be better interpreted as ratio as it signifies not only a relation to the Father, but also to those things which through the Word are made operative powers
. Again,
V De Trinitate, in chapter 5
the word is the beginning of every work
Augustine, De Trinitate V, c. 5, xxx
.

First corollary: though the Father is said to be everything which is and which has to communicate with the Word, nevertheless the Father is able to reveal nothing to the Son or the Word itself. The first is clear through
Augustine, V De Trinitate, chapter 15, de parvis , who says,
the Son not only has itself from the Father, such that it is the Son, but also entirely, such that it is.
Augustine, De Trinitate V, c. 15, xxx
. The second is clear because to reveal conveys imperfection because it argues that there is a non-knowing in the one who a revelation is made, therefore it ought not to be attributed to the divine Word, since it is the true art and declarative knowledge of the truth.

Second corollary: the eternal and infallible word really relate to everything possible or makeable. The opposite is held by
Scotus, distinction 27, question 3, near the end
Scotus, Sent. I, d. 27, q. 3, xxx.
. The corollary is clear through
Anselm, Monologion, in chapter 33 , where he says
by one and the same word God the Father says himself and whatever he makes
Anselmus, Monologion c. 33
and in 34 he says
the work which he makes according to some art, not only when it was made, but before it was made, and after it is dissolved, always is in the art itself not other than what it is itself.
Anselmus, Monologion c. 34
. This corollary is also clear from the sayings of
Saint Thomas, question 4, De Veritate, article 5
where he says
the name word is used to signify something absolute with respect to something joined
Aquinas, De Veritate q. 4, a. 5
and below
the word principally relates to the Father, but as a consequent and as if by accident it is related to the creature
Aquinas, De Veritate q. 4, a. 5
therefore.

Third corollary: just as every intelligible or producible thing is impressed in the Father, so every intelligible thing is expressed through the Word or in the Word. This is clear because the eternal word is not only expressed about the essence as if about an object present to the paternal intellect, but it is also expressed about every intelligibile thing. But all intelligible things are in the Father unitively impressively, therefore the divine Word is expressed about every intelligible thing.

From what has been said it is clear that besides the divine suppositional, there is not absolute or essential Word, or beyond the filial supposite, there is no divinal word. This is clear because
in the Trinity the Word is not said unless the it is the Son
Augustinus, De Trinitate XV, c. 29
, as is clear from
Augustine 5 De Trinitate, chapter 27 .

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p: Second conclusion: the divine Word is a singular term of paternal intellection, emanating from the one understanding by an act that remains internal and of another and declarative of itself. This conclusion is clear because, if it were not singular, it follows in the first place that paternal understanding would not have understood itself, which is false. In the second place, it follows that such a term would not have been produced from the full fecundity of understanding and from every intrinsic perfection, which is false. In the third place, it follows that such a power would not be actuated in the highest degree because such an act of understanding would be intrinsically potential, which is false.

First corollary: though something is produced externally by the same Word, nevertheless it is said that something is produced from the Word because it is not said from the Word. The first part is clear through what is said by Anselmum because
by the same word God the Father speaks himself and whatever he makes
Anselm Monologion c. 33
The second part is clear because the Holy Spirit is produced spiratively by the Word, and nevertheless the Holy Spirit is not spoken because then it would be the word of the word, against
Augustine, on John in principio.
Augustinus, XXX
.

Second corollary: only the Father produces the Word so perfectly or expresses what impresses every level of consubstantial likeness to it, or thus the divine Word exists so similarly to the one speaking that it excludes every level dissubstantial likeness. This is clear through
Anselm, Monologion 40
where from many things said he thus concludes the Word, therefore the highest of the Father
thus is similar to itself, as no offspring thus is, namely, entirely similar to its parent.
Anselm, Monologion 40
.

Third corollary: though the Father having been produced in love is loving, nevertheless the Father having been produced or begotten in the Word is not understanding or knowing. The first is clear through what has been said and the
Master
Lombard, Sent. xx
since the Father and the Son love themselves and us through the Holy Spirit who is love produced spiratively. The second is clear because the Father knows wisdom formally unbegotten, without origin. The opposite of this second part is held by
Scotus, in distinction 27 of book one, in the third question near the end, in the solution of the third argument
Scotus, I, d. 27, q. 3
.

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p: Third conclusion: if it is so properly received, namely for that to which another being follows, and this beginning is said to be what is produced through something, then from the Father with respect to the Son a beginning is admitted within the divine, and the name with respect to the same thing is excluded. The first part is clear because the Son truly and really is generated from the Father, therefore the Son is produced from the Father, therefore the Father is the beginning of the Son. The first consequences is clear because every generation is production, and the second consequence is clear through the acceptance of the principle posited in the conclusion. But the antecedent is a catholic truth. The second part is proved because in the divine there is nothing before or after, therefore there is nothing there to which something else follows, therefore the name of cause has not place there unless with respect to what it is creatable.

The first corollary: though from the three supposites something created is produced, nevertheless from the three uncreated principles no produced thing is co-created. This is clear through the
Master, in distinction 29 , where he says,
the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are not three principles, but one principle of all creatures because from one and the same mode the initiated things, for it is not the case that things are in one mode from the Father, and in another mode from the Son, but the are thoroughly in the same mode
.

Second corollary: it is not the case that something external is immediately caused through the will of the first principle and that the divine knowledge does not terminate to it. This is clear because, just as things are produced through the will and power of God, so they are directed by knowledge, for these are the eternal foundations of all creatures and the first principle, as says
Hugh, in I De sacramentis, part 2, in the last chapter
Hugo de Sancto Victore, De sacramentis I, pars 2, xxx
.

Third corollary: thought God the Father alone is not able to create anything, nevertheless he is able to begin something. The first part is clear because whatever is an external creatable thing is producible by the three divine supposites. The second part is clear because the Father alone begins the Son through the mode of understanding, therefore.
From all of these things, the affirmative part of the conclusion follows.

div.head: Objections and responses
div.p: Against the first conclusion, it is argued, because the Son is in it the World by which the Son and is in it the Son by which the Word, but the Son as divine Son not indicate an operative power nor a declarative power, therefore neither does the Word, and consequently the conclusion is false.

Against the second corollary, if the Word is related to the creature and to the Father either in one respect or by the same relation or by diverse relations, If the second, it follows that there are two distinct relations because with respect to anything possible there is a distinct relation, which does not seem true. Nor the first because a relation of the Word to the Father is an actual relation, but a relation which it has to possible things is only habitual, therefore.

In the third place, against the third corollary, if the Word is expressed, etc., either therefore in the first place it is either equally expressed of the divine essence as it is of other knowing things or according to what comes first and then later. If the first, it follows from the fact that the divine intellect is equally beatifically views for its object any understood things just as the divine essence, which does not seem to be true. If the second is given, it follows that the in the divine there will be priority and posteriority, which was denied above.

In the fourth place, against the sub-corollary, it is argued thus from the saying of Basil regarding word in
Hebrews one ,
upholding all things by the word of his power
Hebraeos 1:3 , where he says that that the Holy Spirit is the Word of Son.

Against the second conclusion: it is argued through
Anselm, Monologion, 40
saying that,
to think the thing of which we have a memory, this is to speak it in the mind
. But in God there are many utterances, therefore there are many intellectual terms there.

In the second place, against the same and the corollary: this is the internal word remaining, which is signified in itself and first through the external word. But the quiddity of the thing, as understood is signified through the external word, therefore the thing understood is the internal word. But such a thing does not emanate from one understanding, therefore.

In the third place against the third corollary, understanding is formally in the Father, therefore also the Word, and as a consequence he understand through a begotten understanding, which is the opposite of the corollary. The antecedent is clear, and the consequence is proved because love formally suits volition and the word formally suits understanding. But an internal volition is not without love, therefore there is no understanding without a begotten word

Against the third conclusion, it is argued through
Damascene, in book one, chapter 2
, where he says that
the Father is the cause of the Son, therefore in the divine the name of cause should be conceded
Ioannes Damascenus, De fide orthodoxa I, c. 2, xxx
.

In the second place, if the name of principle is said in the divine through a relation to the external and internal either this will be equally primary or not. Not the first because then it would be said univocally of the internal and external. Nor would the internal be prior to the external since the internal notionally speaks the external, indeed essentially, nor would the external be prior to the internal since it speaks the internal eternally.

In the third place against the responsive corollary, if the Father is the principle of the begotten word and of produced being, then he is equally the principle of those things or the principle in one way and for the other in another way. Not equally because externally it is the principle in such a way that it is also of procreated being. Not in one way and for the other in another way because both the creature and the word proceed through the mode of understanding, therefore in the same mode. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear because they proceed from God just and artifact from the artist, but this is to proceed through the mode of understanding.

To the first, it is said that the Son is the declarative art of the Father, though it does not appear in this name Son. Whence
Anselm
when he says
by that Word which is the Son
Anselmus, XXX , and conversely he wishes to say that just as in the divine the Son is said notionally, so also the Word.

To the second, it is said that it is related by the same relation to each, nevertheless it does not follows that the creature is eternal or that the divine word is the word of the creature such that the creature speaks the word itself. But it is able to be said thus because this is spoken eternally through through.
In the second place, I say also it is as if the same because the divine Word ought not to be called the word of the creature actively, such that he speaks it, but it is well said passively by virtue of the fact that the creature is said through this.
To the third, it is said that equally primary because in the Father there is one ratio of understanding and being, and there is no diversity or priority there with respect to parts.

To the fourth, it is said that Basilius and other Greek doctors used the name of they used the name of word and image for everything that proceeds in the divine, and thus the Holy Spirit is able to be called the word. But nevertheless properly the name word is said only of that which procced from the understanding, therefore Basilius there used word figuratively and improperly.

To the first against the second conclusion, it is said that not every saying or understanding, speaking loosely, has a term, as was made clear above
in distinction 6
Lombardus, Sent. I, xxx
. This is also held by Hoc etiam tenet
Scouts, in book, distinction 32
Scotus I, d. 32
.

To the second, it is said in the first place that a thing understood is not a word, but rather something produced from an intention because word remains in the intellect.
In the second place, it is said that names signify the understanding of a thing secondarily.

To the third, the consequence is denied, and to the proof when it is said, that internally there is no volition without love, it is said that if the word is is copulative or an indication of an origin and not of formality, then it is conceded, and in this way it is not against what has been said.
In the second place, I say that when taking the word love loosely it is able to be conceded that volition is produced or producing love, nevertheless it is not necessary that it is produced through that same supposite which is love. Whence the Holy Spirit is love produce, nevertheless not through love which is personally the Holy Spirit and is what I call volition in the divine.

And if it is objected against the corollary and response that it follows that there are many wisdoms in the divine because the Father is wise with unbegotten wisdom and the Son is wise with begotten wisdom, here the consequence is denied because this is not more valid than to say God is begotten and God is not begotten, therefore there are several gods. It is clear that the latter is not valid, and thus neither is the former.
To the first against the third conclusion, here it is said that the Greeks use the name cause in a different way than us, therefore the Damascene speaks there in the mode of the Greeks.

To the second, in the first place it would be able to be said according to
Thomam Argentina
Thomas de Argentina, XXX
that the beginning suits God through internal comparison and relation prior to external because the emanation of the divine persons is the ratio of emanation of creatures, and as a consequence it is prior.
In the second place, it is said according to the same in the same place that the beginnig in the divine according to relation to creatures intrinsically and with respect to creatures extrinsically is not said univocally nor equivocally, but anologically, because the relation which he has internally posits something real, but the external relation does not always posit something real.
In the third place, I say that what is essential is not always prior to something notional.

To the third, it is said that not equally nor in the same mode. And to the proof, te consequence is denied becase though emanation of each is according to the intellect, nevertheless it is not precisely according to the same ratio nor in the same mode. Again, it would be able to be said that creatures emanate from God freely and through the mode of the will, but the Word is through the mode of the intellect.

To the first, it is said in the opposition that the Word is said relatively. And to the proof the assumed is well conceded, but nevertheless this is not the complete and sufficient ratio of the Word, and therefore nothing nothing concludes. Similarly, it is said to Augustinum that from knowledge the Word is begotten, but nevertheless this is not the precise ratio of the Word.
To the second, the consequence is denied because not every act of speaking or understanding has a produced term.

To the third, the consequence is denied. And when it is further argued that, if the beginning were through an external realtion, etc., this is denied, but there is only one beginning producing the creature, just as the Master teaches in this distinction.

div.head: Conclusiones
div.p:
Praeterea considerandum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 28, xxx
. The first conclusion of distinction 28: that unbegotten is said relatively about thee Father and unbegotten is said according to the property of the generation and it is said relatively because it is not said according to the substance, for what is said relatively does not indicate substance. Therefore, though begotten and unbegotten are diverse, nevertheless they do not indicate a diverse substance.

Second conclusion: that the Holy Spirit is able to be called not-begotten, though properly it is not called unbegotten because unbegotten is said according to the notion of not-being-able-to-be-born and of origin.

Third conclusion: that Ambrose does not wish to use this term unbegotten on account of the Arian heretic. Thus, it is likewise not necessary to quibble about something on account of the treachery of those falsely interpreting.

Fourth conclusion: that the Father is, and the Son is, and the Holy Spirit is, are diverse because the notion by which the Father is the Father is not the notion by which the Son is the Son or the Holy Spirit is the Holy Spirit

Fifth conclusion: that the Father is is not other than the Son is, though it is one thing to be the Father when the term father is posited from the part of the predicate because this would be to say that there is one thing by which the Father is and another by which the Son is, which is entirely false.

Sixth conclusion: though to be the Father and to be the Son are diverse, nevertheless it is not a diverse substance because these are not said
according to substance but according to relation, because nevertheless what is related is not an accident because it is not changeable.

Seventh conclusion; just as only the Son is called word or image, so also only the wisdom, born, or begotten. And in this which is called born the same notion is understood which is named when it is called word or image. But when it is called wisdom the essence is named, not that the essence is born but it is understood that the Son is begotten which is the essence or the essence is there take for the hypostases, whence wisdom is born, the hypostases is begotten.

Eighth conclusion: that the image sometimes it is said relatively like word, and the Son sometimes it signifies the essence and in that case is said to itself and not relatively. And according to this
Hilary Hilarius de Poitiers, xxx
says that man comes to the common image of the Trinity. And that is all for the distinction.

Est praeterea considerandum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 29
. First conclusion of distinction 29: that the beginning in the divine is said relatively. For Father is the beginning not from a beginning, the Son is the beginning from the beginning, and the Holy Spirit is the beginning from each, namely from the Father and the Son.

The second conclusion: that the Father is called the beginning of the whole deity or divinity not because he is the beginning of the divine essence, but because his the beginning of the Son and of the Holy Spirit in each of which is the whole deity or whole essence.

Third conclusion: that the Father is from eternity the beginning of the Son, and the Father and the Son are not two beginnings of the Holy Spirit, but one, for the Father is not the beginning of the Holy Spirt by paternity nor the Son by filiation, but the Father and the Son by one and the same notion are one beginning of the Holy Spirit, and this notion is active spiration.

Fourth conclusion: that though the Holy Spirit is from eternity or eternally, nevertheless it is not the beginning from eternity because it is not called beginning unless with respect to creatures, which were not from eternity.
Fifth conclusion: that not only the Holy Spirit is the beginning of creatures, but also the Father and the Son, and these three are not three beginnings, but beginning of all creatures.
Sixth conclusion: that the Father is called the beginning of the Son because he begat him, and the Father and the Son are one beginning of the Holy Spirit because the Holy Spirit proceeds from each.

Seventh conclusion: just as the Father and the Son to the creature relatively is called one creator, one lord, so relatively to the Holy Spirit they are or are called one beginning, but to the creature the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit is one beginning, just as one creator ad one lord.
Eight conclusion: though the Son is the beginning from the beginning, nevertheless it should not be conceded that the Son has a beginning of duration, although he has a beginning of origin.

Ninth conclusion: that the Father and the Son by the same notion or relation are called the beginning of the Holy Spirit, but regarding that notion which there notes the beginning we do not have a name, nor is this paternity or filiation, but is some notion which belongs to the Father and the Son by which from eternity the Father and the Son are one beginning of the Holy Spirit. Distinction 30 follows.
